awd_titl_txt: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Consistent Nursing Home Staff Planning under Heterogeneous Service Demand
awd_abstract_narration:
This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award will advance the national health by improving the delivery of health-care to the growing sector of the population served by nursing homes.  Nursing homes are responsible for caring for the frail and vulnerable population of older adults who suffer from diverse chronic diseases, functional limitations and impairments.  They must coordinate distinct caregivers to provide patients with round-the-clock physical and emotional care and assistance.  Because of growing demand due to immutable population demographics, rapidly increasing health-care costs, and escalating nursing staff shortage, proper care for nursing home residents is at-risk. The goal of this project is to improve long-term nursing home quality of care and reduce costs using analytical methods and tools to realize proactive, resident-centered staffing plans.  This project will improve workforce planning, recruitment and allocation decisions for nursing home managers, reduce stress and burn-out by better balancing workloads for nursing home staff, and enhance health outcomes for nursing home residents by better meeting their diverse care needs.  The close involvement of the engineering team with a nursing home operator and national aging health policy experts will also help transform nursing home culture into delivering more resident-centered and home-like care. 

The research objectives will be achieved through the development of a set of innovative models, algorithms, and decision tools. A predictive data analytics model and efficient estimation algorithms will be developed to characterize heterogeneous service need trajectories and length-of-stays of nursing home residents for service demand prediction improvement at the resident level. A two-stage stochastic programming model and efficient numerical optimization algorithms will be developed for consistent nursing home staff planning under service demand fluctuation and uncertainty. To maximize the practical relevance of research deliverables, a decision support system will be also developed to evaluate and validate the work in a real-world nursing home setting through our academic-industrial partnership with Greystone Healthcare Management Corporation and industry-scale solution deployment in their facilities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Delivering high quality care at nursing homes while being mindful about the associated service personnel costs presents a huge challenge to nursing home managers across the nation. This challenge is eminent in face of rapidly growing populations of the elderly and disabled. This challenge escalated in recent years due to healthcare service chain disruptions associated with the COVID-19 pandemic. Many providers in nursing homes are simply worn out by the heavy duties presented to them during the pandemic while thinking of the safety and health of their own and their family.

The central theme of this GOALI project is to develop computational and analytical tools for nursing home managers to develop service provider staffing and scheduling strategies to minimize their labor costs while meeting the standard care need in nursing home residents. Developing such strategies, which are desired to be robust, must account for the uncertainties inherent to the nursing home service system.  There are common fluctuations in heterogenous resident need (both in type and quantity among the case-mix service cohort of the residents) and provider availability (in terms of no show among other changes of short notice on the service capacity). In addition, as mentioned above, uncertainties arise from long-term steady increase of nursing home service demand as well as service system disruptions due to public crises, which is deemed uncertainties with temporal trends and in a non-stationary nature.   

We resort to the scientific literature of stochastic optimization, in particular data-driven optimization in a non-stationary environment, and we strive for effective translation of the tools and techniques into real-world practice. Under equal and synergetic partnership, the two academic sides of this project worked extremely well. While the Purdue team set its focus on developing optimization models and efficient numerical optimization algorithms for case-mix nursing home staff planning and scheduling under uncertainty, the USF team set its focus on developing statistical models and efficient model parameterization algorithms for characterizing heterogenous service need trajectories and length-of-stays of nursing home residents at the individual resident level. To maximize the practical relevance of research deliverables, the two teams together develop a predictive analytics platform based on semi-realistic NH operational data through our academic-industrial partnership with Greystone Healthcare Management Corporation in Florida.

More specifically on the Purdue side, we have progressively studied a series of stochastic programming models for optimal nursing home personnel staffing, scheduling, and task assignment under uncertainty of different sources. We have developed a set of statistical models for case-mix need (both resident census and staffing time) forecasting, which bridges the gap between the traditional stochastic programming framework and the more general data-driven optimization framework. Thus, we lately investigated two data-driven optimization frameworks, namely stochastic lookahead optimization and non-stationary MDP, to deal with sequential decision making under non-stationary environment along with uncertainty. Moreover, we studied the impact of data collection and system identification on the decisions and developed the techniques of efficiently fusing the established understanding of the system and additional intelligence from newly acquired observations in the decision-making. We have continued to explore the leverage of specific statistical models in Bayesian updating in the data-driven optimization frameworks.  

With the support from this grant, I led the efforts to prepare 2 referee-reviewed journal manuscripts, 2 referee-reviewed conference proceedings papers, and 1 referee-reviewed book chapter (directly related to the proposed research) and publish them; led the efforts to prepare 5 referee-reviewed journal manuscripts (indirectly related to the proposed research) and publish them; and participated in the preparation and publication of 6 referee-reviewed journal manuscripts with work primarily conducted on the USF PI Li’s side. The two sides continue to work together on several working papers. Meanwhile, I, my USF colleagues, and the students on both sides gave many research presentations at INFORMS and IISE conferences. We were invited to give seminars at peer institutions (e.g., Georgia Tech, UIUC), international workshops, and companies (e.g., Independence Blue Cross).   

At least 2 PhD students were trained with the support of this grant and 2 undergraduate students were trained with the support of the REU supplement. This grant gave them great opportunities for professional development as well. With the support from this grant, I managed to get exposed to the MDS data in Indiana, which is of great importance to fostering collaboration with nursing and health service researchers. I also managed to start the collaboration with the data core development team at Purdue Regenstrief Center for Healthcare Engineering to develop a dashboard to help NHs visualize the results of our demand modeling and optimal scheduling works.
